Diffusion models generate complex trajectories by modeling trajectory distributions using large-scale offline data.
Diffusion-based planners generate entire trajectories holistically through denoising steps without requiring a forward dynamics model.
Diffusion models address limitations of forward models, such as poor long-term dependency modeling and error accumulation.
Performance gains from increasing denoising steps in diffusion models plateau quickly.
Independent random searches with multiple samples are inefficient as they fail to leverage information from other samples.
Monte Carlo Tree Search (MCTS) demonstrates robust inference-time scalability through iterative simulations.
MCTS refines decisions and adapts based on exploratory feedback, improving planning accuracy with more computation.
Traditional MCTS relies on a forward model for tree rollouts, inheriting its limitations including losing global consistency.
Traditional MCTS is restricted to discrete action spaces and may result in excessively large search trees.
Combining diffusion-based planning and MCTS can enhance inference-time scalability and overcome their limitations.
Monte Carlo Tree Diffusion (MCTD) integrates diffusion-based trajectory generation with the iterative search capabilities of MCTS.
MCTD restructures denoising into a tree-based rollout process for semi-autoregressive causal planning.
MCTD introduces guidance levels as metaactions to dynamically balance exploration and exploitation.
MCTD employs fast jumpy denoising as a simulation mechanism to estimate trajectory quality efficiently.
MCTD enables the four steps of MCTS (Selection, Expansion, Simulation, and Backpropagation) within diffusion planning.
MCTD outperforms existing approaches in long-horizon tasks with superior scalability and solution quality.
This paper proposes the first MCTS-integrated diffusion planning framework that explicitly incorporates the four steps of MCTS.
The three key innovations of MCTD are Denoising as Tree-Rollout, Guidance Levels as Meta-Actions, and Jumpy Denoising as Fast Simulation.
The paper presents experimental results demonstrating the effectiveness of MCTD.
MCTD achieves superior scalability and solution quality in long-horizon tasks compared to existing approaches.
